original_title: Sri Lanka’s CAA cancels gazette that could legitimize pyramid schemes
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Consumer Affairs Authority had cancelled a gazette that may have legalized pyramid schemes by requiring ‘network marketing’ operators to register with the agency.
The gazette has been withdrawn on June 01. Multi-Level marketing, network marketing, direct selling are labels used by pyramid operators to lull their victims, according to activists.
Pyramid schemes are advance fee scams where participants (downliners) pay a fee to the operating company, and those above them (upliners) get a share.
The advance fee scheme is usually disguised by selling a stock overpriced goods, ranging from gold coins to consumer goods.

In order recover the investment, participants in a network or a pyramid has to keep recruiting new members. Typically 99 percent of participants who make up the bottom of the pyramid lose, according to those who study the scam.
Sri Lanka’s central bank named several identified pyramid schemes, which are illegal in Sri Lanka.

Central Bank Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe last warned the public not to get involved in pyramid schemes and if anyone had paid money to such an operation to demand the money back, instead of recruiting others.
Recruiting others is an offence in Sri Lanka under the banking act.  (Colombo/June06/2023)
